snippet.textDisplay:
megaman legends meets chrono cross..

if only i had known the dreamcast had such class back in the day.. perhaps i could have had a cheerier childhood. 

i  was a nintendo kid. if it was on ps1, saturn, or dreamcast, but not on gamecube or n64.. i'd never heard of it outside tomb raider and metal gear solid.

quite sad.. the wonders of bomberman 64, jet force gemini, perfect dark, lost kingdoms, and yugioh: falsebound kingdom only keep your interest in nintendo for so long before you need something new. 

yeah i read about the remake for gamecube. still cant help but wonder what other things sega had in store that i missed though...

snippet.textDisplay:
@vincent207 

Skies of Arcadia stands well above Tales of Symphonia if only because it doesn't draw off of as many anime cliches. The spirit of SoA's story-telling, music, and characters simply puts it in the highest league, alongside games like Chrono Trigger and FF6. ToS is certainly an excellent game, but nothing in it comes close to the epic sweep of SoA's adventure.
snippet.textOriginal:
@vincent207 

Skies of Arcadia stands well above Tales of Symphonia if only because it doesn't draw off of as many anime cliches. The spirit of SoA's story-telling, music, and characters simply puts it in the highest league, alongside games like Chrono Trigger and FF6. ToS is certainly an excellent game, but nothing in it comes close to the epic sweep of SoA's adventure.

snippet.textDisplay: Ridiculously epic RPG. I loved all the different characters throughout the game, especially the main cast and then all of the many crew members you could get. It was awesome how your crew members actually followed the story too, they would have new things to say when the plot changed. If you actually talk to them regularly you appreciate their unique and interesting personalities. Attention to details like that really made the game come alive. The music was just one more part of the epicness.
snippet.textOriginal: Ridiculously epic RPG. I loved all the different characters throughout the game, especially the main cast and then all of the many crew members you could get. It was awesome how your crew members actually followed the story too, they would have new things to say when the plot changed. If you actually talk to them regularly you appreciate their unique and interesting personalities. Attention to details like that really made the game come alive. The music was just one more part of the epicness.

snippet.textDisplay:
(may contain spoliers)

In our darkest hour...

We call upon...

The power...

Of the Ancients!

The game had pirates, pirate ninjas, pirate robots, flying ships, wars, the best fashion disasters ever seen except in Ugly Betty, the best sound effects from characters and it had special attacks that took 10 minutes and filled up your screen with proper mental explosions and A FUCKING MOON SLAMMING ON TOP OF YOUR OPPONENT.

Oh and it was a massive, engaging and entertaining RPG fully worth buying.

snippet.textDisplay: Man, was there a better RPG out then? I bought FFIX and this on the same day back in Nov 2000 but SoA held my attention much better than FFIX did. SoA is just so...wonderfully generic. That might sound like I'm knocking it but nothing could be further from the truth. The game is a gem because it took all the archetypes (vyse and crew are pretty cookie cutter!) but made them interesting and I was happy to "know" these characters for the time I spent playing it.
snippet.textOriginal: Man, was there a better RPG out then? I bought FFIX and this on the same day back in Nov 2000 but SoA held my attention much better than FFIX did. SoA is just so...wonderfully generic. That might sound like I'm knocking it but nothing could be further from the truth. The game is a gem because it took all the archetypes (vyse and crew are pretty cookie cutter!) but made them interesting and I was happy to "know" these characters for the time I spent playing it.
